TALK.START.PARA: —The contributions by various Opposition speakers in this debate on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill suggests two things. The first is that, in line with the speeches that they make on so many other Bills in this place, they have a view that government outlays should be cut, slashed, right across the board. The difficulty is that wherever the opportunity arises they urge more to be spent. They can get away with it until an election campaign. They discovered in the last campaign that it simply was not possible, that ordinary people wake up to that pretty quickly. The acid was put on them: `Tell us where you will cut; tell us what you will spend'. When it was discovered that they could not add up what they would spend and that they could not tell us what they would cut, inevitably they went down in inglorious defeat. Judging from the contributions to this debate, no lesson whatsoever has been learned and they are heading for the same inglorious defeat at the next election.
—I'll take a little wager on that.

—It is illegal to bet on election results, but the honourable senator should see me later. The other thing that is apparent from this debate is that Opposition senators, particularly those who were here during those awful days of the Fraser-Howard Government, simply forget what was done then. The performance of the Hawke Government far exceeds that of the Fraser-Howard Government on the question of road funding. I will elaborate on that for the benefit of the Senate, and Western Australian Opposition senators in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the Government recognises the significance of road funding to the economy generally. We do not need to be told that it is important, and our actions are testimony to the fact that we believe it is important. The Australian centennial roads development program specifically targets roads that will assist our export and import competing industries under the new national arterials category. The main thing to note is that there is no reason whatsoever for the Government to be ashamed of its record. If one compares the total level of road funding provided by the Hawke Government in the last six Budgets with that provided by the Fraser-Howard Government in a comparable period, the Hawke Government is 21 per cent better in real terms. That should answer all of this rot.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the lowest funding since the two world wars.

—Senator Calvert may be forgiven, as he was not here at the time and is just ignorant. Other honourable senators opposite who were here at the time know the facts and, I am sad to say, simply have not acknowledged them during this debate. The Hawke Government has provided an average of $250m a year more than the previous Fraser-Howard Government for road funding. The amount of fuel excise, which has obviously attracted some attention during this debate, that has been devoted to road spending will increase next financial year in line with the indexation arrangements provided for in the legislation. A matter of interest to be noted is the amount of petroleum taxes devoted to road spending in 1981-88. Senator Calvert will remember 1981-82 as the years when, under the Fraser-Howard Government, the economy was out of control. There was a trio of inflation, interest rates and unemployment, all over 10 per cent. It was an absolute mess when John Howard was Treasurer. In those days 16 per cent of petroleum taxes was devoted to road funding, and that has risen to 19 per cent in 1988-89 under the Hawke Government. It astounds me that these facts have not been acknowledged in any of the speeches from the other side. Obviously we would all like to spend more on road funding-even more than with the great job we have done-but, in line with our commitment to the economy generally, we have recognised the need to cut government outlays and, therefore, we have had to balance priorities. We do not have the luxury of making stupid promises that in the end cannot be kept. Rather, we have tried to be honest with the Australian people and that honesty has been accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to go into any great detail about the second part of the Opposition's motion, which concerns the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority, and calls upon us to review their activities. The facts are that the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure is already undertaking that task. My understanding is that it is to report by October this year. Given that that review is already being done, one would imagine that at least that section of the Opposition's motion is irrelevant.

I turn to other points that have been raised during this debate. There has been criticism of the way the Government indexes its funds under its roads programs. Measured against the consumer price index, road funding has been rising faster in recent times, so it is hardly logical to suggest that in some way that is a penalty on the users of roads. In the long term obviously the difference between the two will go up and down. I doubt very much whether anyone can predict with stunning accuracy exactly what will occur in the future. Having said that, I doubt very much whether there will be any real difference. At the moment the non-farm deflator is rising at a slightly faster rate than the CPI. It is not a criticism which I would either accept or be prepared to debate at any length. It is just too silly.

Much attention has been given during the debate to the Hume Highway and achieving four lanes. It is obvious, particularly to anyone who has driven on the highway recently, that considerable progress has been made. Already 500 kilometres of 815 have been converted to four lanes. That is 61 per cent of the total objective. Obviously the Federal Government's strategy has been the right one-to concentrate on those sections of the highway which have the heaviest traffic. As a result it is estimated now that 80 per cent of vehicle kilometres travelled on the Hume Highway are on four-lane sections.

Recently the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) announced a long term strategy for national highways. In New South Wales he has advanced construction of the Cullerin Range deviation at a cost of $79m and the Yass bypass at a cost of $50m. Both of these projects and the Goulburn bypass will commence next year, 1989-90. Major expenditure will be directed initially to the Cullerin Range and the Goulburn bypass, with preconstruction activity on the Yass bypass. The Mittagong bypass, to which Senator Michael Baume was referring, as I recall, in quite hysterical terms on Friday when this was being debated, will be completed in 1991-92, not 1993-94, as he suggested for some strange reason. That is certainly not the case. In Victoria the Hume will be duplicated between Melbourne and Wodonga, and this work will include completion of the Wangaratta bypass at a cost of $93m and the Euroa bypass at a cost of $43m. That will leave the Albury bypass, which will be considered post-1993. If the Hume Highway is to be the centrepiece of any road funding debate, again the Government's record is commendable and I have no difficulty in defending it.

There have also been a number of references, including one by Senator Crichton-Browne, to road deaths. Obviously, concern for road deaths is not limited to any one section of the Parliament. I would hope it is a concern shared by us all. It is not good enough to lay all the blame for deaths on our roads at the feet of inadequate road funding. Obviously accidents are caused by the interaction of a number of things. The state of the road is one of them. The weather conditions applying at the time are another. One would imagine that perhaps the most important factor that would influence road deaths was the person behind the wheel. That, quite clearly, is a very big problem. No matter now much we spend on roads, if people choose to drive when they are not sober then road deaths will continue at a rate that none of us would like to see. If people continue to ignore the requirement to wear seat belts, death and injury will remain at rates higher than we would like to see. Obviously, what is going to be needed in those cases is a change in community attitude.

If honourable senators take the opportunity to look at the Government's road safety strategy they will see that that is where the effort is being directed. I think that they will have to acknowledge that the runs are on the board in terms of success. The fatality rate in Australia, compared to that in other countries, has shown a dramatic reduction since 1975, with the 1987 figures being the lowest for 24 years. Only this week the New South Wales Minister for Transport, Mr Baird, announced that his State's road toll this year was the lowest for 27 years. Obviously the number of fatalities has gone down, and hopefully that trend will continue. Of course, neither the State governments nor the Federal Government can be complacent about the trend. We will all have to work together to make sure that we change the attitudes of those who continue to place themselves and, unfortunately, innocent people at risk because of the attitude that they take when they get behind the wheel.

I turn now to some comments made by Senator Lewis. He suggested that when errors in Telecom Australia's by-law amendments were brought to its notice it chose not to act to correct those errors prospectively. This is simply not the case. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which, I might say, includes as members Senator Stone, Senator Bishop and Senator Patterson-people with whom one would imagine Senator Lewis could manage some contact-picked up some errors in a number of Telecom by-law amendments in early 1988. I doubt very much if this Government needs to worry too much about that, given that the errors dated back to May 1980. The amendments were found to be void as they had not been before the Parliament for the requisite number of days.

Telecom moved to remake those by-laws that had become void as soon as the error was brought to its notice. Telecom was subsequently involved in a lengthy exchange of correspondence with the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to establish that the remade by-laws were in fact prospective and not retrospective. The Committee allowed these by-law amendments to be made, and the former Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support gave a commitment to introduce validating legislation as soon as possible. The telecommunications part of the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 is in fact a fulfilment of that undertaking. The Bill enables Telecom to make by-laws to correct the errors. These by-laws will be subject to committee scrutiny once again.
Having covered those points, which I think were the main ones raised during the debate, may I say that the Government rejects the Opposition's amendment. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bush flier and a bush lawyer!

—As Senator Calvert says, I have been a bush flier and a bush lawyer. I have been a bush pilot in Alaska; I am a flight instructor, a glider tug pilot and a glider instructor. I know my way around the industry and I know the difficulties the industry has been facing, especially under complete cost recovery. It is very unreasonable for the Government to single out the aviation industry to pay for its entire costs. In fact, last year, we were told in a committee hearing that the Government actually recovered 108 per cent of the cost-8 per cent more than the cost of operating the industry. That is cost recovery with a vengance. The country, and the Government specifically, should take a look at aviation as a service to this country, as a benefit to this country, and not try to squeeze every last cent out of it as a revenue gesture. The Government should recognise the industry for what it is-an essential part of the transportation system of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall now deal specifically with the amendment. The Government has instituted a policy of 28 days recovery on outstanding debts. The Opposition wishes to amend it to read 45 days recovery. On the face of it, it looks like a good thing. Any time that the operators of aircraft in this country can be given a better break or a better chance to pay their bills over a longer period it is a good thing in general because many operators have been pushed to the wall by exorbitant government charges and regulations. They are really fighting to stay in business, especially the flying school operators and the charter operators.

I have had consultations with the Government and the Government has convinced me of the benefit of retaining the 28-day system. It is really a commentary on perhaps the inefficiency of the bureaucracy-it is ironic-that the bureaucracy would actually charge more money to collect the debts on a 45-day basis. It is probably best to leave it on a 28-day basis because it would increase costs for the bureaucracy to collect these bills on a 45-day basis. I have been convinced by the bureaucracy that there would be an increase, and it is probably to its own detriment that it has convinced me because that means that it is not being efficient in its own right, and honourable senators can believe it as much as they are sitting here tonight that those costs would be passed on to the industry itself. We would have to pay, the industry would have to pay, all aircraft users would have to pay and all passengers carried by the airlines would have to pay if the recovery period were extended to 45 days.

For this reason I find that I am forced to oppose this amendment which, on the surface, looks like a reasonable amendment to help the aircraft industry. In fact, because of the way the charges are collected, it would actually cost the industry more and the increase would be passed on. For those reasons I cannot support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to what my learned colleague had to say about the collection of fees. I am glad that he spoke to the Government. Perhaps now if I speak to him, having an erudite and informed mind, he might see that there is another side to the equation. Far from increasing the cost to the industry by proposing that the accepted commercial practices of Australia be followed, it may well act as a factor in reducing the costs to an already acutely overburdened industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not lose sight of the fact that commercial aviation in Australia at any level is not a lucrative pastime. No-one in his right mind would buy aircraft or maintenance facilities and try to earn a living from it. Anyone who looks at the annual reports of Qantas Airways Ltd will find that the return on capital invested is very low. It is about one-third or one-quarter of the return that any other commercial enterprise would produce. Anyone who looks at the charter operators and flying school operators-and thousands of Australians are trying to make a living out of such operations-will find that their return on capital is something of the order of 1 per cent or 2 per cent.

It is a desperately difficult business to make a living out of and it is being made much worse by the financial irresponsibility of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). As I said in my speech, neither of those bodies has the first idea about the realities of the commercial world. I said that the CAA had a vague idea of what the aviation industry was about but the FAC did not have the slightest idea. I am sorry that I will not live long enough to see the FAC learn the first elements of that industry because it is quite beyond it.

Let me put this into perspective. I can remember when there was no charge to register an aircraft in Australia, or pay an air navigation charge. I can remember when charges came in. It is a long time ago. The charges were then subjected to rises of about 15 per cent per annum to pay for the cost of the airway services and the airports.

Some years ago the Government commissioned Mr Bosch to make an inquiry into the whole funding of the aviation industry in Australia. The Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery reported that, if the Government corrected the gross inefficiencies in the Department of Civil Aviation, as it was then administering the aviation arena, it would be permissible and practicable for the industry to go to 100 per cent cost recovery in 10 years.

The tacit assumption, as Senator Sanders says, is that we should have cost recovery and user pays for aviation. I do not mind that being done, but if it is done I, as an aircraft owner, want a rebate on my personal income tax because I pay personal income tax for a whole range of services that the Government sets out to provide to me. If the Government is to double tax me I want a rebate on that double tax, and so does everyone else in the aviation industry. That is one argument about user pays.

The second argument is that no-one has control over the user pays doctrine. As an aircraft owner and operator, I cannot say that I do not want a particular service, yet I am subject to the most extravagant overprescription and, without any recourse at all, I am required to pay. I have no formal channel through which I can register my protests. There is no industry channel or pathway through which I can tell the FAC or the CAA what I want. Even if I could, they would not listen, so I suppose it is all rather pointless. Surely, if there is to be a user pays concept, I am entitled to be heard and to say what I want before I am charged for it.

The third point is that it is a very one-eyed philosophy. We have State railways which lose millions and millions of dollars a day and no government, irrespective of its political persuasion, worries about that because it is seen that there is a community benefit.

There is a community benefit in aviation. Where would we be with our present huge balance of payments deficit if we did not have the tourists coming into this country? The little old widow who lives in the suburbs of Sydney or Melbourne might never see a tourist, but the economic impact of the trade in tourism benefits her in indirect ways. There are thousands of examples of the community deriving a benefit from aviation, yet this Government, as did its Labor predecessor, the Whitlam Government, clings violently to the concept that anybody who flies an aeroplane or flies in one has to pay 100 per cent of the cost.

When I am speaking about 100 per cent of the cost, let me go back to Mr Bosch because he said that, if the inefficiencies in the industry are cleaned up, it is possible to go to 100 per cent cost recovery in 10 years. What happened? The Labor Party in two years went to 108 per cent of outlays recovered. There is no argument about this. I have heard the FAC and the CAA argue that really the accounting system was a bit rocky, but the Budget statements outline quite accurately what moneys the Government attributed to or spent on the aviation industry. In the last year-about two years before the FAC and the CAA were created-the Government recovered 108 per cent of the amount it spent and the galling part of it was that the Government did not correct any of the inefficiencies in the old Department of Aviation. In fact it compounded them. We have had these monsters, the FAC and the CAA, created. They are quite out of control and answerable to no-one. That is why we have a Senate inquiry looking into them.

Let us look at what is happening with these people for whom Senator Sanders thinks a 28-day recovery period is appropriate. They are both commercially incompetent bodies. When I was speaking earlier I had a file from one of the clients of the FAC. The amount was $13.20. The file is about half an inch thick. The person paid the sum of $13.20 when the bill was presented. The FAC has kept on billing him. When the first account came in after payment this person wrote to the FAC explaining that the bill had been paid and put a photocopy of the statement with the cheque of payment on it. That was in December of last year. The letter has never been acknowledged by the FAC. The person involved keeps getting monthly statements saying that his account is in arrears. The FAC gave evidence to the Senate Committee on Monday that it cost it about $30 to $35 to send out an account. Over a sum of $6.60 which is in dispute, it expended $200 to $300 in its bookkeeping practices. It will not even acknowledge the letter that it has been given.

If one goes around the aviation industry one will not find a hundred examples of this sort of commercial practice by the FAC and CAA; one will find thousands. I have in my files letters from people. Indeed, the Senate Committee has received letters showing where the FAC and the CAA, in particular, have remitted charges. In other words they have billed people in the industry for charges. When they have been challenged they have cut and run after a lengthy dispute. They have said, `No, we recognise that those charges are invalid'. They may well cut and run on those issues because some of the charges that have been made by both the FAC and the CAA are illegal; they will not stand up in court.

I inform Senator Sanders that it is against this background of administrative incompetence that we have to judge the proposition that the time for payment be extended beyond 28 days. I am sure, as an innately fair and just person, Senator Sanders would realise that there are these ogres out to take a lien over one's aircraft if one does not pay a $5 account within 28 days. The opportunity of granting a 45-day period during which protests can be made is really a reasonable move to make.

Furthermore, one has to look at it in the light of accepted business and commercial practice in Australia. No-one now pays accounts within 28 days. I would be about the only guy, perhaps besides Senator Sanders, in the country who does. I can assure Senator Sanders that the business community does not settle an account in 28 days. The best terms of payment one can get with big accounts is 60 days. Many accounts are on a 90-day basis and some are even on a 120-day basis. It is quite wrong for this Government, given the background of the aviation industry, to be pushing such a restrictive practice. The FAC and the CAA are commercially irresponsible. The FAC is the equivalent in the commercial world of what Pol Pot was in the political world. They are utterly out of control and irrational. I will not aid and abet their irrational processes in any way at all. I want them brought to account. I want them to justify their charges. Putting in a reasonable period of payment, as the Opposition is doing, is one way of bringing it about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up a point that Senator Sanders made. Quite rightly, as a bush pilot and as a bush lawyer, he admitted that pilots and aircraft owners are being pushed to the wall. He then turned around, on the other hand, and said that he has been convinced by the Government that 45 days is not more efficient than 28 days. In this day of overdrafts, computer banking and all of those things which go with it I would like to know how Senator Sanders can be convinced by the Government, unless it is the promise of preferences in the coming election in Canberra that has twisted his ear on this issue. There is no way in the world I can understand how the Government can say it costs more to collect 45-day bills than 28-day bills. We are not opposing all the other sections relating to the air navigation charges which, as my colleague Senator MacGibbon has said, are rather steep. As a token gesture, Senator Sanders might like to explain how it will cost more money to collect in 45 days rather than 28 days.

—This is a House of review and we depend on debate to solve our problems. I am glad to enter into this debate. As the Government explained it to me, the reason is that only half the bills would be collected at 45 days. The other half would still be collected at 28 days. This would involve two different accounting procedures.
—All they have to do is print two different accounts.

—No, it would involve two different accounting procedures and for the Government this is difficult. It would confuse them mightily. It would therefore cost the taxpayer or the users of the industry more. This was my understanding. This was the way the Government explained it to me. I may have misrepresented the Government's argument but I am willing to listen. I would like to hear the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is representing the Government, explain to all of us, so that we may all hear. Perhaps, with his golden words, with his mellow and mellifluent voice, he can convince us all of the propriety of the Government's position on this. I would certainly like to listen to the Minister to see whether I have the Government's line straight. Perhaps he can explain to Senator Calvert why he should withdraw his amendment. I would like now to hear the Minister expound the truth in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked to expound the truth. This is something I propose to do. It is something that I always stick by and cleave to. There is no other course for a Government Minister, as unfortunately Senator MacGibbon may never learn. The amendment moved by Senator Calvert is the same as the amendment that, I understand, was moved by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in the other place. So it does not come as any surprise to us that this amendment should be moved. The Government opposes it and for many of the reasons put in the initial argument of Senator Sanders. I have been asked to elaborate on that argument and I propose to do so. But before I do so may I say that Senator Calvert may have given the game away in an unfinished sentence he uttered. He seemed to argue for a shorter period than a longer one because convenience is typical of electronic funds transfer.
—Perhaps I should have said computer taxing.

—However, the penalty free period is necessary to allow for the administrative processes involved in the payment of accounts. Currently 28 days is allowed from the issue of an invoice before penalty charges apply for late payment of air navigation charges under the Air Navigation (Charges) Act. A 28-day period is a normal commercial practice to allow for the payment of accounts. It is comparable with the period allowed by organisations such as Bankcard.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment would not affect the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) or the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) charges as their charges are levied under their respective Acts and not under the Air Navigation (Charges) Act. A comparison with the arrangements applying before 1985 when the period was reduced from 45 days to 28 days is invalid as most operators paid annual air navigation charges in advance before 1985. Charges at that time had to be paid, on average, 137 days in advance to avoid penalty charges. Charges are now paid monthly in arrears and can be paid, on average, 45 days after the date of the subject flight without incurring penalty charges. The Calvert amendment would benefit only a small number of operators; it would not benefit avgas operators as they are not subject to the Department's landing charges.

The most significant effect of the charge would be to increase the cost to the industry of the collection of charges and the inconvenience involved in the checking of accounts. I think this is the point that Senator Sanders was making in his remarks. At present, the Civil Aviation Authority and the Department of Transport and Communications accounts are processed concurrently by the Authority. This arrangement allows industry to receive a single invoice from the two organisations, greatly reducing the time necessary to check accounts and simplifying the payment of accounts. The charge in the penalty free period for the Department's accounts would introduce a significant difference between the Department's accounts and the Authority's accounts. It would no longer be possible to operate a common accounting system. It would be necessary to send separate accounts for the Department and the Authority. The introduction of a new accounting system for the Department would increase the cost of the system, which is attributable to the industry, as the Department's accounts are at present processed by the Authority system with only a marginal increase in costs. The requirement to check and pay two separate accounts would inconvenience industry and directly increase its costs.

In summary, the proposed change would increase costs to industry both directly and indirectly, would destroy an aspect of the present arrangements which industry finds very convenient, would move away from normal commercial practice, and would provide only a dubious benefit to a small number of operators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that we have had such an erudite, if somewhat dubious, expression from the Government as to why it is introducing this measure. In light of that, I have every confidence that I will be able to convince my learned friend Senator Sanders to support me on this matter. I would like to ask the Minister, first of all: How many accounts does this Government pay in 28 days to its millions of creditors? I thought we introduced a private member's Bill here some while ago, which the Government was remarkably reluctant to support, that provided that the Government would settle its accounts within 28 days. I would be very surprised if the Government did, on average, meet a 28-day deadline on paying its creditors.
—Does it pay any penalties?

—No, I do not think it would pay any penalties. I think that until the Government puts its own house in order it cannot go throwing stones at someone else's. Senator Cook talked about air navigation charges being paid in advance. I remind him that, in the days when air navigation charges existed, they were virtually the sole charge paid by an aircraft operator. One did not pay for a licence renewal for any of the licences; one did not pay for examinations; one met no other charges in operating an aircraft other than one's annual air navigation charge-it was all wrapped up in that. It was quite a moderate charge, too. I think the first air navigation charge I paid, about 20 years ago, was about $80. The important point is that there was only one charge.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have a huge plethora of charges-not one but dozens of them-and those charges are going up by 500, 600 and even 800 per cent. We are not talking about small money here. We can look at the rentals that the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is trying to extort out of people for properties which are owned by the people of Australia but which have been transferred, in a bit of shonky bookkeeping, to the FAC. The FAC is now trying to earn a profit of at least 7 1/2 per cent in real terms on the notional value of those assets which have been transferred to it by this generous Government-assets which were paid for, probably completely in all cases, by the people of Australia.

Let me give some examples of these charges. I had a letter last year from an aircraft radio technician at Archerfield in Brisbane. He got a directive from the FAC that he would have to pay a user charge of $500 per year to allow him to go on to the airport. There was no consultation with him about the imposition of this charge, and there was no consultation with him on the user pays principle. This particular operator works from his home, where his workshop is. That is where his telephone, his office and his maintenance facilities are. He drives on to the airport for an aggregate period of about two hours a week, basically to pull radios out of aircraft radio racks. He then takes them home. When he is working on those aircraft, pulling those radios out, he is always working in hangars for which a ground rental is paid to the FAC, or in a parking lot for which the aircraft operator pays a parking fee. This person is being asked to pay $500 for the privilege of going on to the field because, under the by-laws, the FAC is entitled to charge him as a supplier of goods or services to an FAC airfield.

I think that sort of charge is absolutely unbelievable. It means that if Senator Sanders gives advice to me, as an aircraft owner, as to how I should operate either my own aircraft or another aircraft, Senator Sanders is a supplier of a service and, since I am based on an FAC airfield, the FAC is quite entitled to charge Senator Sanders a fee. That is how ridiculous the law is. But these are the great powers that, in a moment of weakness, this Parliament gave the FAC, and similar great powers to impose charges are vested in the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). If the air navigation charge were the only charge, the Minister would not have any argument out of us at all. But it is not like that.

Let me give another example. I was phoned up the other day by one of the big fuelling agents on an FAC airport. He said, `The FAC wants $500 per tonne per fuelling vehicle I own'. He said, `I have a number of trucks that are between 10 and 14 tonnes, and I have one 20-tonne refueller. That formula means I will pay $35,000 a year extra just for the vehicles I have on this one airport to provide fuel to aircraft'. He said, `On top of that, my site rental allowance, which I pay for the tank farm I have here, has gone up 100 per cent'. Again, there was no consultation-just this fee dropped on someone. I rang up the FAC and asked, `Are you going to impose a fee on fuelling agents?'. The reply was, `Well, yes; it is under discussion'. I said, `What is the proposition?'. I was told, `Oh, well, it is under discussion; we cannot discuss the details'. I asked, `Well, is it on the basis of $500 per tonne per fuelling vehicle?'. The answer was, `Well, it may be; it may not be. I am sorry; we cannot discuss it'-the old flim-flam stuff that we get and have got ever since the FAC and the CAA were created. They will not discuss charges at all before they are imposed. They will not discuss them with the industry, and they will not discuss them with the members and senators of this Parliament when we ring up in the legal and legitimate pursuit of our duties. All that happens is that a letter arrives in the mail informing of these extortionate charges.

Not only does the FAC want this $500 per tonne for fuellers; in the same letter which advised of those charges it said, `We reserve the right to put a levy per litre on fuel sold at a future date'. I could go on, but it is late at night. The point I want to emphasise is that we have a user pays doctrine. We have no control in the Parliament, or in the industry, over the charges that are being levelled and levied by an irresponsible FAC and CAA.

Senator Cook talked about the difficulty of having two accounting practices. The Government has created not two but three accounting practices. Whereas we once had a Department of Civil Aviation or a Department of Transport, it has created a Department of Transport and Communications, a Civil Aviation Authority and a Federal Airports Corporation. The Government has trebled the administrative overheads imposed on the aviation industry. If one goes around the airports one will find the airport users protesting about the new CAA headquarters because the FAC will not have the CAA in them and vice versa. We are getting a plethora of buildings on airfields that we need like we need a hole in the head. It is big money. It not only costs to construct the buildings; it also costs to keep them going. Those overhead costs have been trebled by this Government for no benefit whatsoever to the community.

There are probably 1,100 people employed by the Federal Airports Corporation. Nearly 7,600 people are employed by the Civil Aviation Authority. There are another 400 employees in the old Department of Transport dealing with internal, not overseas, aviation matters. In total, about 8,800 Australian public servants and members of the Corporation are on the payroll, looking after just over 7,000 aircraft on the register. In the United States, instead of having a greater number of public servants than aircraft, the number of public servants would be one-third the number of aircraft on the register. It is against this background that the reasonable proposition is advanced for an extension of time for the payment of accounts to 45 days, to accord with normal industry practice of between 60 and 90 days, so that the greatly overburdened aviation community has time to challenge the FAC and the CAA as to whether the account is correct and whether those bodies are justified in raising it.

If I recall correctly, when Senator Sanders was speaking on this matter last week he made the point that it was not the little people in general aviation who were involved. In fact, they are the people who are most involved. It is not Sir Peter Abeles, or whoever runs Australian Airlines, or the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd who are discomforted by these moves. It is the battler, the person whom you and I know-the person who is worried about his overdraft, who is trying to make ends meet-who is feeling the lash of the accounting and charging practices followed by these bodies. It is on their behalf that I support this amendment so strenuously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have discussed this matter at length. I find that I am in a position of making a decision, somewhat as King Solomon had to do. I do not wish to carve the baby in half, perhaps, but I am somewhat at a loss to reconcile the presentations of Senator MacGibbon and the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook. Senator MacGibbon and I often argue on other topics but we generally see eye to eye on aviation. He being the right wing and I being the left wing of this machine, we generally strike a pretty good balance on our aeronautical progress through the halls of this place. But I am a bit confused, and I hope that the Minister can set me straight. I thought that the Minister just said-and I am sure that the briefing I received from his officials said-that this extension of time would not really affect the small operators, the users of avgas, but only the users of avtur. Avgas, of course, is the mother's milk of the general aviation business. It is what powers the light aircraft of the flight instruction facilities and general aviation in its smaller sense. The turbine fuel is what powers jets. That was my understanding.
—You are right.

—If that is the case, then I feel that this extension would benefit the airlines at the expense of those whom we both hold dear, the general aviation operators, because the airlines and the operators of avtur aircraft-the commuter airlines, I suppose-would be granted a 45-day extension. As Senator MacGibbon has said, the overheads have trebled. I agree with him. What we are talking about is overheads. It would cost more to collect these funds. So, general aviation would be the loser. That is the reason I am opposed to this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the Minister says that this is the truth and because Senator MacGibbon says otherwise, who am I to believe? I am sure that the Minister is not deliberately misleading the Parliament. I am sure that he would not do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are absolutely right.
—Neither am I misleading Parliament.

—I am sure that Senator MacGibbon would not be misleading Parliament purposely, but in his zealousness to present the case of general aviation he might have somewhat enhanced the truth. I can only really take the Government's word and its briefing at face value. I have talked to the Minister's officials. If I found that the Government had not been completely honest in this I suppose that it would then be too late to rectify the damage, but I certainly would not be pleased. I put the Government on notice that I would make it quite plain if I felt that I was being deceived by the Government. All I can do is believe the Government's word and briefing, hope that the facts are as presented and, in this very difficult situation, adhere to my original position that, to protect general aviation from the increasing costs of collecting this charge over a 45-day period, I must support the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refute what Senator Powell has said. She makes out that in some way or other the coalition Government in 1980 was at fault in this matter. The truth of the matter is that the Hawke Government found out what Telecom Australia was doing only around October last year. It introduced regulations to correct the matter then, so it probably found out what had happened in August or September last year. Since then it has tried to rectify the error on behalf of Telecom. The situation is quite clear. No government, whether Liberal-National Party or Labor Party, knew what was happening until the middle of last year, at the earliest. Having been advised by Telecom of what had happened, the Hawke Labor Government is endeavouring to rectify the error by introducing retrospective legislation. Our parties will not support that retrospective legislation, notwithstanding the fact that apparently the Australian Democrats are prepared to do so.

—I find it extraordinary in the context of this amendment that the defence here offered of a former government-particularly one whose party, now in opposition, often takes a holier than thou attitude to ministerial responsibility-is that it did not know what was going on. I find it extraordinary that a former member of that Government should stand up and say, `We are absolved because we did not know what was going on in one of our statutory authorities'. Perhaps we should congratulate the Government for having found out what was going on and for trying to do something about it.

—Senator Powell totally misses the point. Had we found out about it in government, we would have rectified the matter prospectively. In other words, we would have said, `As from now this will not happen'. We would not have introduced retrospective legislation to correct an error in relation to this matter. That is the difference between us and the Labor Party and between us and the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis stated that when the errors in its by-laws amendments were brought to Telecom Australia's notice it chose not to act to fix the errors prospectively.

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom was subsequently involved in a lengthy exchange of correspondence with the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to establish that the remade by-laws were prospective and not retrospective. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee allowed these by-laws amendments to be made when the former Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support gave a commitment to introduce validating legislation as soon as possible. The telecommunications part of the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 is a fulfilment of that undertaking. The Bill enables Telecom to make by-laws to correct the errors. These by-laws will be subject to the scrutiny of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and will come here and lie on the table in the normal way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill was first debated on 7 April, and then we had a little more debate last week. So it has been a rather protracted matter, and I should like the opportunity to deal with some of the matters that have been raised by other senators and also to put on record some important matters of fact that relate to why the Labor Government continues to tamper with our electoral legislation within the framework of compulsory voting.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to begin by looking at the report of the former Electoral Commissioner in New South Wales, Mr Gundy, who chaired a committee on behalf of the State Government of New South Wales inquiring into electoral fraud. That committee simply found that multiple voting had occurred and, indeed, that the integrity of the system was flawed. When Senator Schacht spoke in this debate he raised the matter of the Castle- reagh by-election which I had raised considerably earlier during the course of 1988. I think that it is important to raise the matter here, to put it into the correct context and to put certain facts on the record. Senator Schacht, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and one or two other folk have obviously been acutely embarrassed by the truth of the sting in the tail of the story of the Castlereagh by-election. I would remind honourable senators that when I spoke on 17 March 1988 and tabled the tape of a speech by one John Patrick Begg boasting of his exploits for and on behalf of the Wran Government I did so in this context, and I quote from Hansard:

. . . as we go to the polls on Saturday, the scrutineering that will take place will be most scrupulous on the part of the Liberal Party. It has become of great concern that the laws have been changed to allow people to vote in any subdivision so that we run the risk of having multiple voting.
The same multiple voting that former Commissioner Gundy found had taken place. I continued:

As I have clearly outlined, the Labor Party is there to hang on at all costs. Mr Unsworth has his fall-back plan of trying to hang onto a minority government, to try to force the Governor into a position whereby Mr Unsworth could become, in the terms of the Sunday Telegraph, `not a loser but a martyr'.

So I raised the question of the Castlereagh boasting by Mr Begg, a former employee of Premier Wran, and I think it is important again to place on the record Mr Begg's own curriculum vitae. His name was John Patrick Begg. He was employed by Premier Neville Wran in his Department in 1976. Mr Begg wrote speeches and press releases for Mr Wran, and, after three months, was promoted to the ministerial advisory unit. In 1976 he was made responsible to Premier Wran for restructuring the Department of Industrial Development and Decentralisation. In 1977 he became involved in writing legislation and recommended key appointments to the New South Wales Meat Industry Authority. In 1977 he set up and managed a nine-member trade mission to Saudi Arabia and returned with a $1m three-year meat contract. In 1978 he was responsible for the election campaign in the country and, in his own words:
By astute identification of issues raised the Government's vote from 33.2 per cent to 50.4 per cent.
In 1980 he again boasted-this is in writing in his CV, as quoted in Hansard of 17 March 1988, at page 919-that he:

Organised and managed the Castlereagh By-election campaign culminating in a government win. Coordinated press releases/ads/slogans/protocol and issues. The `Curran for Castlereagh-Your Vote in the Government' campaign is regarded as his most outstanding achievement.

That is the statement that he put in his own CV, but the tape which I tabled in this place reveals that in 1984, when he was addressing a meeting of a group on the Central Coast, he said that the meeting was set up for organisers of a campaign to work against the establishment of power stations in that area. He said:

. . . get your captive audience, and get around and by `em a beer, buy `em a drink, buy `em a steak sandwich, and keep talking, you know? Stooge-for God's sake, this has been done before, you know, like I mean, they read out my-I'll be quite open to you about this, you know-they read out my curriculum vitae. One of the things was the Castlereagh By-election which was a traditional Country Party seat they said the Labor Party had no chance of winning, and once again, getting back to basics, there were beautiful advertising slogans, there was this, there was that, and I just sat down one day and I, you know, sort of got myself and I thought to myself-this is going to be close.
This is Mr Wran's adviser boasting. This is not my allegation; this is Mr Begg's boasting.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the Electoral Commission say?
—He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Now, you know, I then went down-there's one office, the regional newspaper office, and Castlereagh started at Dubbo and went right through to Bourke-it was huge-big electorate-and I went down to the local thing and I went-it took me two days-and I went through twelve months and looked at the obituaries and I got everyone that died in the past 12 months and then I compared them to see if they were on the roll and there were 400 on the roll. So I sent little people out to vote for them on these blokes' behalfs and, do you realise, we won the seat by 330 votes.

As I was reading that quote Senator Schacht asked me what the Electoral Commissioner said. The Electoral Commissioner said, basically, that the boast about having won by 330 votes was not correct. But the important thing about Mr Begg was not that his arithmetic was wrong, but the simple fact that these are the sorts of endeavours and ends to which the Labor Party will go to win at any cost. We look at the amendments to the existing legislation in that context. What did the Labor Government do for the 1987 election? It changed the rules again to enable multiple voting to take place. As former Commissioner Cundy held, multiple voting did take place, as was enabled by the changes to the Electoral Act in 1987 in the State of New South Wales, which followed the precedent of similar changes in 1984 to the Federal electoral Acts to make it easier to cheat on the system.

Now what are we proposing? We are proposing to make it compulsory even for prisoners to vote. Is that on the assumption that most prisoners are Labor Party supporters? Is that a conclusion to which one can reasonably come?
